ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: The Matlab codes for most of the methods presented in this paper are provided in the TACTS toolbox. Supplementary material related to this article can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.physrep.2014.04.001.

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: The following is the Supplementary material related to this article. MMC S1A Matlab toolbox that covers the spectrum of time series analysis techniques used in the analysis of complex, autonomous and nonautonomous systems. It includes methods acting in the frequency, time and time–frequency domain as well as code for phase space and complexity analysis. It also contains time series analysis methods used in the investigation of the interactions between two systems.

ce:section.ce:label: B.1
ce:section.ce:para: The Heun scheme is defined as: x̃n+1=xn+hf(tn,xn),(B.1)xn+1=xn+h2(f(tn,xn)+f(tn+1,x̃n+1),)dxdt=f(t,x). This is a second order integration scheme, calculating a prediction x̃n+1 of the next point in the trajectory using the current point xn and then using that prediction to make a more accurate estimate of the gradient of the line connecting xn to xn+1. Higher order integration schemes also exist that are able to reduce the error further but with this they bring other limitations [209]. It should be noted that care must be taken when integrating systems with a noise term as the algorithm must be adjusted according to Honeycutt [60].

ce:section.ce:label: B.2
ce:section.ce:para: The Lie method is defined by the following differential operator: (B.2)Lo=f1∂∂x1+f2∂∂x2+⋯+fd∂∂xd, where xi are the dimensions of the system, fi≡dxidt(xn1,xn2,…,xnd) and d is the total number of dimensions. The integration scheme is then given by (B.3)[xn+11xn+12⋮xn+1d]=ehLo[x1x2⋮xd], which can be approximated by the Taylor series: (B.4)[xn+11xn+12⋮xn+1d]≈∑k=0Mhkk!Lok[xn1xn2⋮xnd], where M is the order of the expansion (higher M corresponds to a greater accuracy of integration). The proof of (B.3) is given in [210].

ce:section.ce:label: C.1
ce:section.ce:para: Consider integrating equation (20) over −π<n<π, (C.1)∫−ππf(t)dt=∫−ππaodt+∫−ππ∑ω=1∞[aωcos(ωt)+bωsin(ωt)]dt=2πao+∑ω=1∞aω∫−ππcos(ωt)dt+∑ω=1∞bω∫−ππsin(ωt)dt=2πao+∑ω=1∞aωω[sin(ωπ)−sin(−ωπ)]+∑ω=1∞bωω[cos(−ωπ)−cos(ωπ)]. Since ω is an integer, the two summations on the right hand side become 0. Rearranging, this gives an equation for ao: (C.2)ao=12π∫−ππf(t)dt. Similar derivations result in the following equations for aω and bω: aω=1π∫−ππf(t)cos(ωt)dt,(C.3)bω=1π∫−ππf(t)sin(ωt)dt,ω=1,2,3,…. However, this still accounts only for the part of f(t) spanning −π<t<π. To find the coefficients for a function that spans some arbitrary period L there needs to be a change of variable. Setting t′=2πt/L, another function can be defined as g(t′)=f(t) and the new integration variable is given by dt′=2πdt/L. Substituting into the previous equations gives: (C.4)g(t′)=ao+∑ω=1∞[aωcos(ωt′)+bωsin(ωt′)], where ao=12π∫−ππg(t′)dt′,aω=1π∫−ππg(t′)cos(ωt′)dt′,(C.5)bω=1π∫−ππg(t′)sin(ωt′)dt′,ω=1,2,3,…. Then, returning to the original variable: (C.6)f(t)=ao+∑ω=1∞[aωcos(2πωtL)+bωsin(2πωtL)], where ao=1L∫−L2L2f(t)dt,aω=2L∫−L2L2f(t)cos(2πωtL)dt,(C.7)bω=2L∫−L2L2f(t)sin(2πωtL)dt,ω=1,2,3,…. These equations now define the Fourier series for a function over a finite period. Note that ω now represents the standard frequency multiplied by L rather than the angular frequency. The step from here to the discrete Fourier transform is a very small one. The two sets of coefficients aω and bω, corresponding the sine and cosine terms can instead be replaced with a single complex coefficient Aω by using Euler’s formula: (C.8)e2πiωtL=cos(2πωtL)+isin(2πωtL). Using the same basis as before and setting aω and bω respectively as the real and imaginary parts of Aω, the complex Fourier series can then be written as: (C.9)f(t)=∑ω=−∞∞Aωe2πiωtL, where (C.10)Aω=1L∫−L2L2f(t)e−2πiωtLdt. In the discrete case, integrals and summations spanning an infinite range cannot be used. The discrete Fourier transform is therefore defined as [211]: (C.11)F(ω)=∑n=0N−1f(n)e−2πiωnN. Additionally, the inverse transform is defined as: (C.12)f(n)=1N∑ω=0N−1Fωe2πiωnN.

ce:section.ce:label: C.2
ce:section.ce:para: Starting with Eq. (24), the least squares error is defined as: (C.13)S=∑i=1n[xi−f(ti)]2=∑i=1n[xi−(ao+a1ti+a2ti2+⋯+amtim)]2=min., where xi are the data points corresponding to the times ti. To find the least squares error approximation, the first derivatives with respect to the unknown coefficients are used: (C.14)∂S∂ao=2∑i=1n[xi−(ao+a1ti+a2ti2+⋯+amtim)](C.15)∂S∂a1=2∑i=1nti[xi−(ao+a1ti+a2ti2+⋯+amtim)](C.16)∂S∂a2=2∑i=1nti2[xi−(ao+a1ti+a2ti2+⋯+amtim)]⋮(C.17)∂S∂am=2∑i=1ntim[xi−(ao+a1ti+a2ti2+⋯+amtim)]. The condition where S=min. is then found when ∂S∂ak=0 for k=0,1,2,…,m. The following linear equations are therefore derived: (C.18)∑i=1nxi=nao+a1∑i=1nti+a2∑i=1nti2+⋯+am∑i=1ntim(C.19)∑i=1nxiti=ao∑i=1nti+a1∑i=1nti2+a2∑i=1nti3+⋯+am∑i=1ntim+1(C.20)∑i=1nxiti2=ao∑i=1nti2+a1∑i=1nti3+a2∑i=1nti4+⋯+am∑i=1ntim+2⋮(C.21)∑i=1nxitim=ao∑i=1ntim+a1∑i=1ntim+1+a2∑i=1ntim+2+⋯+am∑i=1nti2m. This can then be converted to matrix form x=Ta where (C.22)x=[x1x2⋮xn],T=[1t1…t1m1t2…t2m⋮⋮⋱⋮1tn…tnm],a=[aoa1⋮am]. The vector a can then be found numerically using a matrix equation solver, after which the values can be substituted into (24) to obtain the best-fitting polynomial for the points contained within the window.

ce:section.ce:label: D.1
ce:section.ce:para: Calculating probability distributions adds another level of complexity to time series analysis. This is because the accuracy and precision of the distribution is dependent on the type of binning used. To generate a probability distribution a set of evenly-spaced intervals (bins) needs to be defined between the minimum and maximum amplitude in the time series. An estimate of the probability distribution is then found simply by counting the number of points that fall into each bin.

If small bins are used then it is possible to see more details in the distribution but accuracy is lost due to the finiteness of the time series. If large bins are used then a greater number of points will be allocated to each bin, causing the accuracy to increase but the precision to be lost. The procedure is therefore a balancing act, with the best advice being to avoid either extreme and settle for an optimal bin size somewhere in-between. In particular, the number of bins should be dependent on the amount of data that is binned (i.e. the number of points in the time series, N), which for a Gaussian distributions can be derived as [212](D.1)Number of bins=e0.636(N−1)2/5. Other estimators also use adaptive bin sizes where the size is dependent on the location in the distribution [213].

ce:section.ce:label: D.2
ce:section.ce:para: The significance of certain features in time series can usually be tested by making repeat recordings of the system. However, even then it is possible for systematic bias to skew the interpretation of these features. An alternative approach to test for significance has therefore been developed and is known as surrogate data [201,214]. Starting with a single time series, this technique generates a new time series which preserves the properties that are consistent with a null hypothesis but randomizes all others. Reapplying the same analytical methods to the surrogate time series will therefore reveal the bias in the result.

One of the simplest types of surrogate data are the independent identically distributed (IID) surrogates [215,3]. These are used to test the null hypothesis that the dynamics of the time series can be modelled as any independent random process with a given probability distribution. They are generated by shuffling the order of the data points in the time series, moving each one to a random point in time. The result is a time series with the same distribution as the original but with none of its temporal structure. IID surrogates are most suitable for noisy time series with a flat frequency spectrum [215].

For time series which do contain structure in the frequency spectrum another type of surrogate data can be produced by using the Fourier transform. This is done by randomizing the complex phase of Aω from (C.10) so that each point in the spectrum F has the same amplitude but different values for the real and imaginary parts. A real time series can then be reconstructed from the Fourier transform by making the second half of the transform (corresponding to negative frequencies) the complex conjugate of the first half. The surrogate time series is then given by the inverse Fourier transform: (D.2)f(n)=1L∫−L2L2Aωe−2πiωnLdω. This procedure preserves the frequency spectrum of the original time series but no other properties. A significant problem is that the points in the surrogate time series are forced into a Gaussian distribution [214]. This has important repercussions if the surrogate time series is being used to test for significance in a method that involves probability distributions, such as the information theoretic approach. It also has an impact on phase space methods, since the embedded time series will also have a Gaussian distribution, altering the information about the actual distribution of states. However, for complexity analysis the distribution of states is often the feature that is being tested, which makes these surrogates a viable option.

If the distribution of the data was to be preserved in the surrogates it is important to consider how this will change the null hypothesis of the significance test. For the previous algorithm, the hypothesis is simply that the time series was generated by a linear Gaussian process. It is clear from the examples of stochastic systems in this paper that nonlinearities can drastically alter the distribution (take for example the shapes of the attractors in phase space). Therefore, a new null hypothesis can be formulated where the time series is generated from a invertible nonlinear transformation of a linear Gaussian process.

The following procedure generates surrogates to test this hypothesis using the amplitude adjusted Fourier transform (AAFT) [216,214]. To remove the effect of any nonlinear transformation, the time series is rescaled so that it has a Gaussian distribution. This simply means ordering the data from highest to lowest and substituting corresponding values from an equal-length time series of Gaussian white noise at the same positions in time. The Fourier transform is then applied as before, with the phases of Aω being randomized for every ω. After using the inverse Fourier transform, the distribution is restored by rescaling the surrogate using the data from the original time series.

A problem with the AAFT procedure is that the resulting surrogates do not usually have the same frequency spectrum as the original time series. In order to preserve this spectrum, iterative amplitude adjusted Fourier transform (IAAFT) surrogates are needed [217,216]. In this case, the original time series data is first shuffled and then the Fourier transform of the new time series is calculated. The amplitudes of the Fourier components are adjusted to match the original, after which the data is transformed back to the time domain. As for the AAFT surrogates, the data is rescaled so that it contains the same values as the original time series. However, this process adjusts the frequency spectrum away from the desired distribution. The procedure is then iterated for a second time, transforming to the frequency domain, adjusting the amplitudes to match the original and then transforming back and rescaling. The iterations continue until the order of the data after rescaling converges to the order of the previous iteration.
